subSubSection.paragraph:
Liang (1998) erroneously stated that the name “
Pyrops watanabei atroalbus ( Distant, 1918 )
” was a new combination he proposed while the combination had already been proposed by Nagai and Porion (1996) .
The species is immediately recognized by the following combination of characters:
(1) Cephalic process yellow and strongly inflated apically ( Fig. 1 D–F).
From Latin ater (adj.) ‘black’ and albus (adj.): ‘white’; the species epithet refers to the black and white colouration of the species.

subSubSection.paragraph: VIETNAM : 1 ♂ , 1 ♀ , Da Krong Nature Reserve, Quang Tri Province , 10 Jul. 2011 , 16°37′ N , 106°47′ E , day collecting, Pham & Hoang ( ♂ in RBINS , ♀ in VNMN ); 1 ♀ , Bach Ma National Park, 29 Sep. 2014 , 16°12′ N , 107°52′ E , Tuan ( VNMN ).
THAILAND : 1 ex. ( Fig. 9A ), Chiang Mai Prov. , Maerim District, 18°54′50″ N , 98°56′42″ E , 14 Mar. 2016 , Panaka Jirasuttayaporn.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5.
Pyrops atroalbus ( Distant, 1918 )
comb. nov. , holotype ♂ (BMNH, photographs by D. Croucher). A . Habitus, dorsal view. B . Habitus, ventral view. C . Labels.

subSubSection.paragraph:
There is a discrepancy between the location given on the label of the specimen (“
Tonkin
”) and the one given in the original description ( Distant 1918 ): “ Indochina, Xieng Klouang (R. Vitalis de Salvaza) ”. The latter location is situated in Laos , not far from the places where we have collected specimens in Central Vietnam . Despite our intensive collecting effort in northern Vietnam , we have never found the species in that region. Hence, it seems that the location given by Distant (1918) is more likely to be the correct one.
Nagai & Porion (1996 : fig. 223) erroneously gave “central Taiwan ” as the type locality.
The species is known from one location in Laos , one in Northern Thailand , and two in Central Vietnam .
